TopicTitle: Pol to Bop: Has anyone done the math (or experimented with the options?)

Articles.Content:
A standard Joolian exploration problem as depicted below. (Ignore the elliptical orbit, that's just a spent stage).

If you are landed on Pol and want to land on Bop, what is the most efficient method you have found?

The two basic options are:

1) Wait until the Pol/Bop ascending/descending node, then leave Pol and burn to drop your periaspsis down to Bop and get the intercept directly at the opposite node.

2) Drop your periapsis further to Tylo and use Tylo to assist with the inclination change.

Method 1 is clearly easier, requiring less planning and takes less time. 2 May be cheaper, but Tylo is a bit too good at slingshotting and you may end up at the right inclination but with a crazy apoapsis that you then need to bring down with additional bouncing around.

Edited June 14, 2014 by allmhuran
I think 1 is your best option. While the inclination dV may be cheaper with option 2, you run the risk of really screwing up your orbit and actually using more dV to correct.
I would choose option 1 if only because I'm so bad at making gravity assists work as intended.
Catch it right and you're only looking at a few hundred m/s of delta-v anyway ... why bother with Tylo unless you want an elegant solution?

I would also choose option 1. Plane changes are relatively cheap far away from Jool, but orbital insertions can be quite expensive. I haven't checked the numbers, but my intuition is that a transfer from Tylo to Bop requires a bigger insertion burn than a transfer from Pol to Bop.

Yeah, the last two times I did it I went with option 1. But since I'm doing something even more ridiculous than usual, I'm wondering if the savings of option 2 (if any) are worthwhile.

Broken down, the considerations are these: Assuming a perfect gravity assist (or series of gravity assists) from Tylo to get the Bop inclination and altitude, we have the following cost options:

Option 1: A=(Cost of getting periapsis from Pol to Bop) + B=(relative tangential velocity at Bop given a Pol apoapsis) + C=(cost of highly inclined approach to Bop)

Option 2: D=(Cost of getting periapsis from Pol to Tylo) + E=(relative tangential velocity at Bop given a Tylo periapsis) + F=(cost of orbital adjustments for gravity slingshots).

Trivially, A is smaller than D.

I do not know which of B or E is smaller (assuming perfect inclination either way, which is cheaper - Bop approach from Tylo's altitude, or Bop approach from Pol's altitude), nor what the value of C is when going from Pol to Bop.

I can easily keep F to less than 50 m/s.

Edited June 14, 2014 by allmhuran

Most efficient method known to me is using Alexmoon's calculator. It allows you to select moons and calculate transfers between them.

Or perhaps Trajectory Optimization Tool but I have no experience with it.

Of course since it is just a few m/s I never actually bothered with it and did it this way:

- eject from Pol at inclination point

- lower your periapsis to cross Bop's trajectory

- at the crossing adjust your orbital periapsis to meet Bop there the next (or second next) time

- fix the inclination during circularizing burn

Now, to compare your two methods:

Using Alexmoon's calculator, the transfer from Pol to Bop costs somewhere around 300 m/s (250~350)

Transfer from Pol to Tylo, ignoring Tylo circularization is about 220 m/s

Transfer from Bop to Tylo, ignoring Tylo circularization (applies also to optimum ejection from Tylo and circularization on Bop) is about 100 m/s

Total for Pol->Tylo->Bop is therefore around 320 m/s

In my opinion they're very similar dv-wise but the Tylo transfer is much harder to set up and you're very likely to set it up suboptimal.

Edited June 14, 2014 by Kasuha

Good numbers. Given that, the Tylo slingshot should turn out to be somewhat cheaper, since this inverse of this stage:

"Transfer from Bop to Tylo, ignoring Tylo circularization (applies also to optimum ejection from Tylo and circularization on Bop) is about 100 m/s"

Is nearly free (via slingshot).... unless that's just insertion delta v.

Scratch that, I misunderstood... I see that is indeed only insertion delta v. So yeah, pretty much the same.

Edited June 14, 2014 by allmhuran

The last time I went from Pol to Bop I was very low on delta-v so I first transferred from Pol to Bop at the node, and meeting Bop where it's closest to Pol's orbit, with a very small inclination change. Then I used about 3 or 4 Bop gravity assists to get my inclination in line and my apoapsis down, and the final Bop insertion took very little delta-v. I think it's possible to get a Pol-Bop transfer for under 200 m/s that way.
